Award.AwardTitle: Measuring R&D knowledge diffusion through large databases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research increases understanding of the impact of federal research funding on economic outputs by developing a new data source that enables new analyses of science, engineering, and innovation. The project will improve the measurement of R&D knowledge diffusion by collecting and linking three types of public data: federal government grants and contracts, U.S. patents, and licensing agreements. This project assists the federal government in communicating the impact of public R&D investments to policy makers, stakeholders and citizens. By understanding the factors that lead to commercial licensing of federal government research, the federal government can invest its funds more strategically and increase the productivity of R&D investment, accelerate innovation and increase the United States? economic competitiveness. In addition, this project directly addresses the goal to create a federal government that is responsive and accountable to its citizens.

The project builds a data platform on an extensible, common data schema shared by all data types, including patents, publications, and awards. Collecting and combining these data will create a unique, novel, big data set. The government interest section of a U.S. patent will be used to link patents and federal government investments, which can be found in grant databases and the federal procurement data system. Patent licensing is opaque and not generally available; however, reports of technology licensing agreements are filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, providing a rich public dataset on technology development. This project will use machine learning to extract these mentions, building a licensing agreement database. Specifically, this database will then be combined with the limited information available in the USPTO's licensing database, and linked to types of federal investment. This approach represents a new way to measure R&D impact by tracing knowledge flows through multiple sources and points in time. The project will demonstrate the viability of collecting licensing data on a large scale and linking the data back to the supporting federal government investments. The resulting data set will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evaluation of outcomes of government-sponsored research and development (R&D) is receiving increasing levels of attention. Knowledge diffusion is a key metric in assessing the impact of these investments in research. Measures of knowledge diffusion include (1) R&D funding, (2) patents, and (3) licensing agreements. Each of these measures can be thought of as a measurable step in the generation and transmission of new knowledge. The difficulty is in making the connections between these steps, because there is no persistent identifier that is assigned when funding is awarded and then carries through to licensing; however, we can make connections between the steps using unique identifiers such as award numbers and patent numbers. This project links the knowledge flows through the R&D system, producing a linked set between R&D funding, patents, and licensing agreements.

In this project we have created a unique, novel dataset by linking three types of public data: federal government grants and contracts, U.S. patents, and patents mentioned in company financial documents submitted to the U.S. Security and Exchange Commission (SEC filings). Data on federal government investment is found in grant databases and the federal procurement data system. The government interest section of a U.S. patent is used to link patents and federal government investment. Patent licensing is opaque and not generally available; however, reports of licensing agreements (and other patent events) are filed with the SEC.

This project used machine learning to extract patent mentions and classify them as licensed, building a database of patents that are commercially valuable enough to be mentioned in the SEC database. We have processed all quarterly filings made available by the SEC extending from the present back to 1995, when public records were first made electronically available. We have extracted patent references from this database of more than 12 million records. We linked those patents to federal government research investments through the government interest section in the patent record. This section in a patent acknowledges direct government funding used in the development of the invention represented in the patent. Next, we linked the award numbers, where mentioned, to federal research grants and contracts as recorded in the following databases:

  • National Science Foundation (NSF) Awards Database
  • National Institutes of Health (NIH) exPorter
  • USAspending.gov
  • Federal Procurement Data System
  • DARPA public reports
  • NASA list of patents
  • Department of Energy Office of Scientific and Technical Information database

The resulting dataset will be made public via supplementary data to a published journal article.

In total, we processed 12,272,907 filings from the SEC electronic (EDGAR) database found with SRI’s text analytic tool (the Valet engine), finding 203,675 paragraphs containing patent references, and a total of 28,920 references to unique numbers. To determine accuracy of this extraction, we drew a random sample of 500 paragraphs deemed to contain a patent reference. These 500 paragraphs were inspected by a human analyst to determine if the asserted patent reference was legitimate; this inspection yielded 26 false positives, resulting in a precision of 94.8%.

Using the information extracted from government interest statements, we found 435 patents supported by the federal government and mentioned as licensed in the SEC. 387 of these patents had an award number; 645 award numbers were extracted. 82% of these award numbers were matched to government databases. The SRI team produced a dataset of the following, where the data element was available:

  • Licensor company
  • Licensee company
  • Company information: Name, location, size, industry code (NAIC or SIC)
  • Patent number
  • License date

This dataset links patents to their original sources of funding and explores the paths from funding to patents, especially on the contract side, which has not been explored to our knowledge.

 Intellectual merit: This study demonstrated the feasibility of linking award, publication, patent, and license databases to examine knowledge diffusion. This dataset sheds new light on the commercial value of patents. Ultimately, it supports the assertion that only very few patents represent true innovations.  If every patent represented an innovation, we would expect to have found many more patents in the SEC database.

Broader impacts: This study showed how knowledge moves through the U.S. innovation ecosystem which is valuable for the evaluation of federal R&D investments, which are known to be imperative to U.S. economic competitiveness. Understanding the value and diffusion of this knowledge will help U.S. competitiveness in the future. This dataset will help many researchers study questions and generate new insights related to innovation, patents, and knowledge flows.
